article:
2022 Indonesia Open

The 2022 Indonesia Open was a badminton tournament that took place in Jakarta, Indonesia, from August 23 to August 28, 2022. The tournament was the 13th edition of the Indonesia Open and was part of the 2022 BWF World Tour.

# Tournament

## Venue

The tournament was held at the Istora Gelora Bung Karno in Jakarta, Indonesia. The venue has a seating capacity of 7,000 spectators and has hosted numerous international badminton tournaments, including the 2014 and 2018 Indonesia Open.

## Point distribution

The tournament followed the BWF World Tour rules, with points awarded to players based on their performance in each round. The points were distributed as follows:

* Winner: 7,000 points
* Runner-up: 5,200 points
* Semifinalists: 3,200 points
* Quarterfinalists: 2,030 points

## Prize money

The total prize money for the tournament was $775,000, with the winner of each event receiving $63,500.

# Men's singles

## Seeds

The seeds for the men's singles event were:

1. Kento Momota (Japan)
2. Viktor Axelson (Denmark)
3. Anders Antonsen (Denmark)
4. Rasmus Gemke (Denmark)
5. Lee Zii Jia (Malaysia)
6. Loh Kean Yew (Singapore)
7. Kantaphon Wangcharoen (Thailand)
8. Anthony Ginting (Indonesia)

## Finals

The final match of the men's singles event was played between Kento Momota and Viktor Axelson. Momota won the match in straight sets, 21-19, 21-17.

## Top half

### Section 1

The top half of the men's singles draw was led by Kento Momota, who was seeded number one. Momota won his opening match against Kantaphon Wangcharoen, 21-17, 21-15. He then faced off against Lee Zii Jia in the second round, winning in straight sets, 21-14, 21-18. In the quarterfinals, Momota defeated Loh Kean Yew, 21-19, 21-17.

### Section 2

The second section of the top half was led by Lee Zii Jia, who was seeded number five. Jia won his opening match against Lukas Hönig, 21-11, 21-14. He then faced off against Kantaphon Wangcharoen in the second round, losing in straight sets, 21-14, 21-18.

## Bottom half

### Section 3

The bottom half of the men's singles draw was led by Anders Antonsen, who was seeded number three. Antonsen won his opening match against Khosit Phetpradab, 21-12, 21-15. He then faced off against Rasmus Gemke in the second round, losing in straight sets, 21-18, 21-17.

### Section 4

The fourth section of the bottom half was led by Rasmus Gemke, who was seeded number four. Gemke won his opening match against Ygor Coelho, 21-12, 21-15. He then faced off against Anders Antonsen in the second round, winning in straight sets, 21-18, 21-17.

# Women's singles

8. Ratchanok Intanon (Thailand)

## Finals

The final match of the women's singles event was played between An Se-young and Nozomi Okuhara. Young won the match in straight sets, 21-14, 21-17.

## Top half

### Section 1

The top half of the women's singles draw was led by An Se-young, who was seeded number one. Young won her opening match against Gregoria Mariska Tunjung, 21-11, 21-12. She then faced off against He Bingjiao in the second round, winning in straight sets, 21-17, 21-18. In the quarterfinals, Young defeated Tai Tzu-ying, 21-19, 21-17.

### Section 2

The second section of the top half was led by He Bingjiao, who was seeded number five. Jia won her opening match against Line Christophersen, 21-13, 21-12. She then faced off against An Se-young in the second round, losing in straight sets, 21-17, 21-18.

## Bottom half

### Section 3

The bottom half of the women's singles draw was led by Nozomi Okuhara, who was seeded number three. Okuhara won her opening match against Yvonne Li, 21-8, 21-11. She then faced off against Ratchanok Intanon in the second round, winning in straight sets, 21-13, 21-17.

### Section 4

The fourth section of the bottom half was led by Ratchanok Intanon, who was seeded number eight. Intanon won her opening match against Dinar Dyah Ayustine, 21-16, 21-15. She then faced off against Nozomi Okuhara in the second round, losing in straight sets, 21-13, 21-17.

2022 Badminton Asia Team Championships

The 2022 Badminton Asia Team Championships was a badminton tournament held from May 15 to May 21, 2022, in Selangor, Malaysia. The tournament was organized by the Badminton Asia Confederation (BAC) and was the fourth edition of the event.

# Medalists

## Medal table

| Rank | Team | Gold | Silver | Bronze | Total |
| 1 | China | 1 | 1 | 1 | 3 |
| 2 | Japan | 1 | 1 | 0 | 2 |
| 3 | South Korea | 0 | 0 | 2 | 2 |
| 4 | Indonesia | 0 | 0 | 1 | 1 |

# Squads

The participating teams in the 2022 Badminton Asia Team Championships were:

* China
* Japan
* South Korea
* Indonesia

# Tournament

## Venue

The tournament was held at the Axiata Arena in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.

## Seeds

The teams were seeded based on their performance in the previous edition of the tournament. The top four teams were seeded as follows:

* China (1)
* Japan (2)
* South Korea (3)
* Indonesia (4)

## Draw

The draw was conducted based on the seeding. The teams were divided into two groups for the group stage.

# Men's team

China won the final match with a score of 3-0.

article:
Christianization
================

Christianization refers to the process of converting individuals, communities, or entire nations to Christianity, often involving the spread of Christian teachings, practices, and institutions. This phenomenon has occurred throughout history, from the early Christian era to the present day, and has been facilitated by various means, including missions, individual conversions, temple conversions, and colonialism.

Missions
--------

Christianization has been driven by Christian missions, which have sought to spread the faith to diverse regions and cultures. These missions have taken various forms, from individual evangelists to institutionalized efforts sponsored by churches, governments, and other organizations.

Individual conversion
-------------------

Individual conversion to Christianity has been a fundamental aspect of Christianization. This process typically involves several key rituals and practices, including:

### Baptism

Baptism is the ritual of initiation into the Christian faith, involving the application of water as a symbol of spiritual rebirth and purification. In many Christian traditions, baptism is seen as a prerequisite for full membership in the faith community.

### Eucharist

The Eucharist, also known as Communion or the Lord's Supper, is a ritual in which believers consume bread and wine as a means of spiritual nourishment and communion with God. This practice is rooted in the Last Supper, which Jesus shared with his disciples before his crucifixion.

### Confirmation

Confirmation is a sacrament or rite of passage in which individuals are reaffirmed in their faith, often accompanied by the laying on of hands and the bestowal of spiritual gifts. This practice is found in various Christian traditions, including Catholicism, Eastern Orthodoxy, and some Protestant denominations.

Places and practices
-------------------

Christianization has involved the conversion of various sacred sites, including temples, shrines, and other places of worship. This process has taken different forms, depending on the cultural and historical context.

### Temple conversion within Roman Empire

During the Roman Empire, Christian missionaries converted many pagan temples to Christian use, often incorporating existing structures and artifacts into their new worship practices.

### Temple and icon destruction

In contrast, some Christian authorities have advocated for the destruction of pagan temples and icons, seen as threats to the faithful and obstacles to the spread of Christianity.

### Other sacred sites

Christianization has also involved the conversion of other sacred sites, including synagogues, mosques, and indigenous spiritual centers.

Nations
--------

Christianization has had a profound impact on the history and cultures of various nations, often shaping their institutions, values, and practices.

### Roman Empire to Early Middle Ages (1 to 800)

Christianization in the Roman Empire was a complex and multifaceted process, involving both voluntary and coercive means.

#### Christianization without coercion

In some regions, Christianization occurred without significant coercion, as individuals and communities voluntarily adopted the faith.

#### Constantine and the goal of Christianization

The conversion of Emperor Constantine to Christianity marked a turning point in the history of Christianization, as the faith gained imperial patronage and support.

#### Albanians

The Albanians, a people living in the Balkans, were among the earliest Christian nations, with a long history of conversion to Christianity dating back to the 2nd century.

#### Germanic conversions

The Germanic tribes, including the Goths, Vandals, and Lombards, were converted to Christianity through a process of gradual acculturation and assimilation.

#### Frankish Empire

The Frankish Empire, established by Charlemagne, played a significant role in Christianizing the Germanic tribes and expanding the faith throughout Europe.

#### Christianization with coercion under Justinian I

The Byzantine Emperor Justinian I implemented policies of Christianization through coercion, resulting in the forced conversion of many pagan communities.

### Ireland

Ireland, with its rich Christian heritage, was an early center of Christianization, with missionaries like Saint Patrick spreading the faith to the Irish people.

### Great Britain

Christianization in Great Britain involved the conversion of the Anglo-Saxons, who were initially resistant to the faith but eventually adopted it through a process of gradual assimilation.

### Italy

Italy, with its rich cultural and historical heritage, was an early center of Christianization, with missionaries like Saint Ambrose spreading the faith to the Italian people.

### Greece

Greece, with its ancient pagan traditions, was converted to Christianity through a process of gradual acculturation and assimilation.

### Caucasian Albania

Caucasian Albania, a region in the Caucasus, was an early center of Christianization, with missionaries like Saint Gregory the Illuminator spreading the faith to the Albanian people.

### Armenia, Georgia, Ethiopia and Eritrea

Armenia, Georgia, Ethiopia, and Eritrea were among the earliest Christian nations, with a long history of conversion to Christianity dating back to the 1st century.

### A seismic moment on the Iberian Peninsula

The Iberian Peninsula, with its rich cultural and historical heritage, was an early center of Christianization, with missionaries like Saint James the Greater spreading the faith to the Spanish and Portuguese people.

### Europe and Asia of the High and Late Middle Ages (800 to 1500)

During this period, Christianization continued to expand throughout Europe and Asia, with the establishment of new kingdoms, empires, and trade routes.

### Language and literature

Christianization had a profound impact on language and literature, with the development of new languages, such as Latin and Greek, and the creation of a vast body of Christian literature.

### Bulgaria

Bulgaria, with its rich cultural and historical heritage, was an early center of Christianization, with missionaries like Saint Boris spreading the faith to the Bulgarian people.

### Serbia

Serbia, with its ancient pagan traditions, was converted to Christianity through a process of gradual acculturation and assimilation.

### Croatia

Croatia, with its rich cultural and historical heritage, was an early center of Christianization, with missionaries like Saint Jerome spreading the faith to the Croatian people.

### Bohemia/Czech lands

Bohemia, with its ancient pagan traditions, was converted to Christianity through a process of gradual acculturation and assimilation.

### Poland

Poland, with its rich cultural and historical heritage, was an early center of Christianization, with missionaries like Saint Adalbert spreading the faith to the Polish people.

### Hungary

Hungary, with its ancient pagan traditions, was converted to Christianity through a process of gradual acculturation and assimilation.

### Scandinavia (Sweden, Norway and Denmark)

Scandinavia, with its rich cultural and historical heritage, was an early center of Christianization, with missionaries like Saint Olaf spreading the faith to the Scandinavian people.

### Romania

Romania, with its rich cultural and historical heritage, was an early center of Christianization, with missionaries like Saint Demetrius spreading the faith to the Romanian people.

### Northern crusades

The Northern Crusades, launched by the Teutonic Knights and other Christian orders, aimed to convert the pagan populations of Eastern Europe to Christianity.

### Lithuania

Lithuania, with its ancient pagan traditions, was converted to Christianity through a process of gradual acculturation and assimilation.

### Kievan Rus'

Kievan Rus', a medieval state in Eastern Europe, was an early center of Christianization, with missionaries like Saint Vladimir spreading the faith to the Russian people.

### Iberian Reconquista

The Iberian Reconquista, a series of military campaigns launched by Christian kingdoms against the Moorish invaders, aimed to reclaim the Iberian Peninsula for Christianity.

Early colonialism (1500s–1700s)
---------------------------

During this period, Christianization expanded to new regions through colonialism, with European powers establishing colonies and spreading Christianity to indigenous populations.

### Disease

The Columbian Exchange, which occurred as a result of European colonization, introduced new diseases to indigenous populations, leading to widespread mortality and social disruption.

### Spanish and Portuguese India, Mexico and the Americas

Spain and Portugal, with their rich cultural and historical heritage, were among the earliest European powers to establish colonies in the Americas, Africa, and Asia, often spreading Christianity to indigenous populations.

### French Canada, North America, west Africa and the West Indies

France, with its rich cultural and historical heritage, was another major European power to establish colonies in the Americas, Africa, and Asia, often spreading Christianity to indigenous populations.

### Dutch Indonesia, South Africa, Curaçao, New Guinea

The Netherlands, with its rich cultural and historical heritage, was another major European power to establish colonies in the Americas, Africa, and Asia, often spreading Christianity to indigenous populations.

### British North America, Australia, New Zealand, Asia and Africa

Britain, with its rich cultural and historical heritage, was another major European power to establish colonies in the Americas, Africa, and Asia, often spreading Christianity to indigenous populations.

### In the United States

The United States, with its rich cultural and historical heritage, was an early center of Christianization, with missionaries like Saint John the Baptist spreading the faith to the indigenous population.

Africa (19th to 21st centuries)
-----------------------------

During this period, Christianization continued to expand in Africa, with the establishment of new missions and the spread of Christianity to various African cultures.

### Zaire

Zaire, a region in central Africa, was an early center of Christianization, with missionaries like Saint Joseph spreading the faith to the Zairian people.

### Tanzania

Tanzania, a region in eastern Africa, was an early center of Christianization, with missionaries like Saint Augustine spreading the faith to the Tanzanian people.

### Other countries

Christianization has continued to expand in other African countries, with the establishment of new missions and the spread of Christianity to various African cultures.

Decolonization
--------------

During this period, Christianization continued to expand in newly independent countries, with the establishment of new missions and the spread of Christianity to various cultures.

Global Christianization

article:
**Better Call Saul Season 6**

Better Call Saul Season 6 is the final season of the American television drama series Better Call Saul, created by Vince Gilligan and Peter Gould. The season premiered on April 18, 2022, on AMC, and consisted of 13 episodes, concluding on July 15, 2022.

**Cast and Characters**

### Main

The main cast for Season 6 includes:

* Bob Odenkirk as Jimmy McGill/Saul Goodman
* Jonathan Banks as Mike Ehrmantraut
* Rhea Seehorn as Kim Wexler
* Patrick Fabian as Howard Hamlin
* Michael Mando as Nacho Varga
* Giancarlo Esposito as Gus Fring
* Mark Margolis as Hector Salamanca
* Ray Campbell as Tyrus Kitt
* Kerry Condon as Stacey Ehrmantraut

### Recurring

The recurring cast for Season 6 includes:

* Mark Proksch as Matt Morris
* Emily Ratajkowski as Eleanor
* Brian Goodman as Tom Schnitzler
* Eian Roy as Young Mike
* Ben Belaayoua as Beto
* Dennis Boutsikaris as Dan Wachsberger
* Lavell Crawford as Huell
* Craig Cackowski as Bill Oakley

### Guests

The guest cast for Season 6 includes:

* Tony Dalton as Lalo Salamanca
* Alon Aboutboul as Casper
* Mark Kassen as Donald Margolis
* Shawn Doyle as Cal Federman
* Michael Irby as Marco
* Danny Trejo as Victor

**Production**

### Development

The development of Better Call Saul Season 6 began shortly after the conclusion of Season 5. Vince Gilligan and Peter Gould continued to serve as showrunners, with Gilligan also serving as an executive producer. The season was produced by High Bridge Productions, Crunchy Fruit Films, and Sony Pictures Television.

### Writing

The writing team for Season 6 consisted of:

* Vince Gilligan
* Peter Gould
* Gennifer Hutchison
* Thomas Schnauz
* Gordon Smith
* Ann Cherkis
* Heather Bellson

### Casting

The casting process for Season 6 began in 2020, with the addition of Emily Ratajkowski to the cast as Eleanor. The season also featured the return of several recurring and guest actors from previous seasons.

### Filming

Filming for Season 6 began in April 2021, with locations including Albuquerque, New Mexico, and Los Angeles, California. However, production was delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which forced the cast and crew to adhere to strict safety protocols.

### COVID-19 Delays

The COVID-19 pandemic had a significant impact on the production of Season 6. Filming was delayed multiple times due to outbreaks on set and in the surrounding area. The cast and crew were required to undergo multiple rounds of COVID-19 testing and adhere to strict safety protocols.

### Odenkirk's On-Set Heart Attack

In July 2021, Bob Odenkirk suffered a heart attack on set, which forced production to be halted for several days. Odenkirk underwent emergency surgery and made a full recovery.

### Averted IATSE Strike

The International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees (IATSE) threatened to go on strike in 2021, which would have impacted the production of Season 6. However, the strike was averted through negotiations between the union and producers.

**Episodes**

Season 6 consists of 13 episodes:

1. "Wine and Roses"
2. "Carrot and Stick"
3. "Fun and Games"
4. "Hit and Run"
5. "Black and Blue"
6. "Atomic Loans"
7. "Plan and Execution"
8. "Point and Shoot"
9. "Fun Town"
10. "Bad Choice Road, Part 1"
11. "Bagman"
12. "Something Unforgivable"
13. "Waterworks"

**Broadcast**

Better Call Saul Season 6 premiered on April 18, 2022, on AMC, and concluded on July 15, 2022. The season was simulcast on AMC+, and was also available to stream on various platforms, including Hulu and Amazon Prime Video.

**Reception**

### Critical Response

Season 6 received widespread critical acclaim, with many praising the performances, writing, and direction. The season holds a 94% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, with an average rating of 9.2/10.

### Part 1

The first half of the season received significant attention for its character development and plot twists. Many praised the performances of Bob Odenkirk and Jonathan Banks, who both received critical acclaim for their portrayals of Jimmy McGill and Mike Ehrmantraut.

### Part 2

The second half of the season was also praised for its character development and plot twists. Many praised the performances of Rhea Seehorn and Patrick Fabian, who both received critical acclaim for their portrayals of Kim Wexler and Howard Hamlin.

### Critics' Top Ten List

Several critics included Better Call Saul Season 6 on their top ten lists, including:

* The New York Times: 1st
* Variety: 2nd
* Rolling Stone: 3rd
* Entertainment Weekly: 4th
* The Hollywood Reporter: 5th

**Accolades**

Better Call Saul Season 6 received numerous awards and nominations, including:

* Emmy Awards: 13 nominations, 2 wins
* Golden Globe Awards: 2 nominations
* Screen Actors Guild Awards: 2 nominations
* Writers Guild of America Awards: 2 nominations

**Home Media**

Better Call Saul Season 6 was released on Blu-ray and DVD on November 22, 2022.

**Related Media**

### American Greed: James McGill

In 2022, AMC released a documentary series exploring the true story of James McGill, the man who inspired the character of Saul Goodman. The series features interviews with people who knew McGill and examines the events that shaped his life.

### Talking Saul

In 2022, AMC released a podcast series exploring the making of Better Call Saul. The series features interviews with the cast and crew, as well as behind-the-scenes stories and insights.

### Slippin' Jimmy

In 2022, AMC released a short film series exploring the backstory of Jimmy McGill. The series features three short films, each of which delves into a different aspect of McGill's life.

### Filmmaker Training

In 2022, AMC released a series of filmmaking tutorials, which feature guidance from the cast and crew of Better Call Saul. The series covers topics such as writing, directing, and acting.

2022–23 ICC Men's T20 World Cup Africa Qualifier

The 2022–23 ICC Men's T20 World Cup Africa Qualifier was a 2022-23 cricket tournament that took place in Uganda from July 21 to July 31, 2022. The tournament was the fifth edition of the ICC Men's T20 World Cup Africa Qualifier and served as a qualifying tournament for the 2024 ICC Men's T20 World Cup in the Africa region.

# Teams
The tournament featured nine teams from the ICC Africa region, which includes countries from sub-Saharan Africa. The teams that participated in the tournament were:

*  Botswana
*  Cameroon
*  Ghana
*  Kenya
*  Malawi
*  Mozambique
*  Namibia

*  Uganda

## Sub-regional qualifiers
Before the main tournament, sub-regional qualifiers were held to determine which teams would participate in the main tournament. The sub-regional qualifiers were played in four regions: East Africa, West Africa, Southern Africa, and Central Africa. The top teams from each region qualified for the main tournament.

### East Africa
The East Africa sub-regional qualifier was held in Tanzania from January 10 to January 15, 2022. The teams that participated in the qualifier were:

*  Kenya

Kenya won the qualifier, with Rwanda finishing second and Tanzania finishing third.

The West Africa sub-regional qualifier was held in Gambia from January 20 to January 25, 2022. The teams that participated in the qualifier were:

*  Gambia
*  Ghana
*  Sierra Leone

Ghana won the qualifier, with Gambia finishing second and Sierra Leone finishing third.

### Southern Africa
The Southern Africa sub-regional qualifier was held in Namibia from February 5 to February 10, 2022. The teams that participated in the qualifier were:

*  Botswana
*  Mozambique
*  Namibia

Namibia won the qualifier, with Botswana finishing second and Mozambique finishing third.

article:
University College London (UCL) is a public research university located in London, England. It is one of the largest and most prestigious universities in the UK and is a member of the prestigious Russell Group.

# History

## 1826 to 1836 – London University
University College London was founded in 1826 as University College, London, which was the first university in England to be open to students of any class or profession. The university was established by a group of individuals who were dissatisfied with the existing system of education in England, which they believed was elitist and exclusive. The university's founders, including Jeremy Bentham, James Mill, and Henry Brougham, were committed to providing education to people of all backgrounds and professions.

## 1836 to 1900 – University College, London
In 1836, University College, London was granted a royal charter by King William IV, which gave it the power to award degrees. The university began to expand its teaching and research activities, and by the mid-19th century, it had established a number of new faculties, including the Faculty of Medicine and the Faculty of Laws.

## 1900 to 1976 – University of London, University College
In 1900, University College, London merged with King's College London to form the University of London, with University College serving as one of the constituent colleges of the university. During this period, the university continued to expand its teaching and research activities, and it established a number of new departments, including the Department of Economics and the Department of Physics.

## 1976 to 2005 – University College London
In 1976, University College, London became a separate university, known as University College London, and was granted full autonomy by the University of London. The university continued to expand its teaching and research activities, and it established a number of new faculties, including the Faculty of Social and Historical Sciences and the Faculty of Mathematics and Computer Science.

## From 2005
In 2005, University College London underwent a major reorganization, which led to the establishment of a number of new faculties and departments. The university also invested heavily in new research facilities and infrastructure, including the construction of a new library and a number of new research centers.

# Campus and locations

## Bloomsbury
University College London's main campus is located in Bloomsbury, which is a central London neighborhood that is home to a number of other universities and research institutions. The campus is situated around Tottenham Court Road and Gower Street, and it is within walking distance of many other major London landmarks, including the British Museum and the University of London's Senate House.

## UCL East
In 2017, University College London announced plans to establish a new campus in East London, known as UCL East. The new campus will be located in the Olympic Park, which is a major regeneration area in East London. The campus will provide a range of new teaching and research facilities, including a new library and a number of new research centers.

## Other sites
University College London has a number of other sites throughout London, including the University College London Hospitals (UCLH) and the University College London Medical School. The university also has a number of satellite sites in other parts of the UK and around the world, including in Singapore, the United Arab Emirates, and China.

## Student housing
University College London provides a range of student housing options, including on-campus accommodation and off-campus apartments. The university's on-campus accommodation is located in a number of different locations, including in Bloomsbury and in other parts of London.

## Environmental initiatives
University College London has a number of environmental initiatives, including the UCL Energy Club, which aims to reduce the university's energy consumption and carbon emissions. The university also has a number of sustainability programs, including a programme to reduce waste and a programme to promote sustainable transportation.

# Organisation and administration

## Governance
University College London is governed by a number of different bodies, including the UCL Council, which is the university's governing body, and the UCL Senate, which is responsible for academic matters. The university's Vice-Chancellor is the chief executive officer and is responsible for the day-to-day management of the university.

## Faculties and departments
University College London is organized into a number of different faculties and departments, including the Faculty of Arts and Humanities, the Faculty of Engineering Sciences, and the Faculty of Laws. Each faculty and department is responsible for a range of academic programs, including undergraduate and graduate degrees.

## Finances
University College London is a self-financing institution, and it generates a significant portion of its income from tuition fees and other sources. The university also receives funding from a number of external sources, including the UK government and other research funding agencies.

## Terms
University College London operates on a semester-based system, with two semesters per academic year. The university also offers a range of online and part-time programs, including online degrees and part-time graduate programs.

## Logo and colours
University College London's logo is a combination of the university's initials and a number of other elements, including a torch and a shield. The university's official colours are blue and gold.

## Memberships, affiliations and partnerships
University College London is a member of a number of different organizations and partnerships, including the Russell Group, the European University Institute, and the University of London. The university also has a number of partnerships with other research institutions and industry partners.

# Academic profile

## Research
University College London is a major research institution, and it has a number of research centers and institutes, including the UCL Energy Institute and the UCL Institute of Education. The university's research activities are focused on a range of different areas, including health sciences, engineering, and social sciences.

**2022–2023 Mpox Outbreak**

The 2022–2023 mpox outbreak is a global pandemic of the monkeypox virus, which was first identified in the Democratic Republic of the Congo in 1970. The outbreak began in May 2022 and has spread to over 90 countries, affecting thousands of people worldwide.

**Background**

### Emergency Preparedness Prior to Outbreak

In the years leading up to the outbreak, the World Health Organization (WHO) and other global health authorities had been monitoring the situation in Africa, where mpox was endemic. The WHO had also established protocols for responding to outbreaks, including the development of diagnostic tests and vaccines.

### Endemic Mpox in Africa

Mpox has been present in Africa for decades, with the first reported cases in the Democratic Republic of the Congo in 1970. The virus is typically found in the tropical rainforests of central and western Africa, and is transmitted to humans through contact with infected animals or contaminated materials.

**Outbreak Characteristics**

### Phylogenetics

The 2022 outbreak was caused by a distinct variant of the mpox virus, known as clade IIb. This variant was first identified in the UK in May 2022 and was found to be distinct from the clade I and III variants that were previously known to cause human disease.

### Long Incubation Periods

The incubation period for mpox is typically 6-13 days, although it can range from 5-21 days. This long incubation period made it challenging for public health officials to track the spread of the virus and identify potential cases.

### Mild Clinical Manifestations

The majority of people infected with mpox experience mild symptoms, including fever, headache, and muscle aches. In some cases, the virus can cause more severe symptoms, including rash, lesions, and respiratory problems.

### Fear of Zoonotic Spread

There was concern that the mpox outbreak could be zoonotic, meaning that it could be transmitted between humans and animals. However, further investigation suggested that the outbreak was primarily driven by human-to-human transmission.

**Chronology**

### Deaths Outside of Africa

As of March 2023, there have been over 30 reported deaths outside of Africa, primarily in Europe and North America.

**Transmission**

### Transmission Patterns

The mpox virus is primarily transmitted through close contact with an infected person, including skin-to-skin contact, kissing, and sharing of personal items. The virus can also be transmitted through contact with contaminated surfaces or materials.

### Wastewater Surveillance

Wastewater surveillance has been used to track the spread of the mpox virus in some countries. By analyzing wastewater samples for the presence of the virus, health officials can identify potential outbreaks and take steps to contain them.

**Interventions**

### Testing and Containment

Public health officials have used a variety of interventions to contain the outbreak, including testing for the virus, contact tracing, and quarantine. Isolation protocols have also been established for people with confirmed cases of mpox.

### Vaccination

Several vaccines have been developed to protect against mpox, including the Jynneos vaccine, which has been approved for use in the US and EU. Vaccination campaigns have been launched in several countries, with the goal of protecting high-risk populations and preventing further transmission.

**Social Aspects**

### Misinformation

There has been a significant amount of misinformation circulating about the mpox outbreak, including false claims about the severity of the disease and the effectiveness of vaccines. Public health officials have worked to address these misconceptions through social media campaigns and other outreach efforts.

**Responses**

### World Health Organization

The WHO has played a key role in responding to the mpox outbreak, providing guidance and support to countries affected by the outbreak. The WHO has also established a coordinating committee to oversee the international response to the outbreak.

### Countries

Countries have responded to the outbreak in a variety of ways, including establishing testing and contact tracing protocols, launching vaccination campaigns, and implementing travel restrictions. Some countries have also taken steps to mitigate the economic impact of the outbreak, including providing financial support to affected businesses.

### Dependent Territories

Dependent territories have also been affected by the outbreak, including the US territories of Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands. Health officials in these territories have worked to establish testing and contact tracing protocols, and to implement vaccination campaigns.

article:
**Carl Friedrich Gauss**

Carl Friedrich Gauss was a German mathematician and physicist who made significant contributions to many fields, including number theory, algebra, analysis, geometry, astronomy, and physics. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest mathematicians of all time, and his work has had a profound impact on the development of mathematics and science.

**Introduction**

Gauss was born on April 30, 1777, in the town of Braunschweig, Germany. His early life was marked by a strong interest in mathematics and science, which was encouraged by his family and teachers. He began his formal education at the age of 7, and soon showed exceptional talent and aptitude for mathematics. Gauss's academic career was marked by a series of achievements that would ultimately lead him to become one of the most respected mathematicians of his time.

**Youth and Education**

Gauss's early education began at the Schulfporta, a school in Braunschweig, where he showed exceptional talent and aptitude for mathematics and science. He was particularly drawn to the works of Leonhard Euler and Pietro Cataldi, and his teachers encouraged his interest in mathematics. In 1792, Gauss entered the University of Göttingen, where he studied mathematics, astronomy, and philosophy. Lisa Marie Presley is an American singer, songwriter, and actress. She is the only child of Elvis Presley, the King of Rock and Roll, and Priscilla Presley.

Early life

Lisa Marie Presley was born on February 1, 1968, in Memphis, Tennessee, to Elvis Presley and Priscilla Presley (née Beaulieu). Her father was 32 years old at the time, and her mother was 21 years old. Elvis and Priscilla married in 1967, and Lisa Marie was born a year later. The couple divorced in 1973, and Priscilla was granted custody of Lisa Marie.

Lisa Marie's early life was marked by her parents' divorce and her father's struggles with addiction. Despite this, she was raised in a wealthy and privileged environment, with access to many luxuries. She attended Immaculate Heart High School in Los Angeles and later graduated from the University of Southern California.

Lisa Marie Presley began her music career in the early 2000s, releasing her debut album To Whom It May Concern in 2003. The album was a commercial success, selling over 200,000 copies in the United States. The album's lead single, "Lights Out," was a moderate hit, peaking at number 104 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart.

The album's success was short-lived, as Lisa Marie's personal life was marred by controversy. Her marriage to Michael Jackson, whom she married in 1994, ended in divorce in 1996. She also struggled with addiction and was hospitalized several times for substance abuse.

Lisa Marie Presley released her second studio album, Now What, in 2005. The album was a commercial failure, selling only 25,000 copies in the United States. The album's lead single, "Dirty Laundry," was a moderate hit, peaking at number 114 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart.

Despite the album's commercial failure, Lisa Marie continued to release music throughout the 2000s. She released several singles, including "So Long" and "Slidin'," but none of them achieved significant success.

The album's lead single, "You Ain't Seen Nothing Yet," was a moderate hit, peaking at number 105 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart.

Storm & Grace was a more introspective album than Lisa Marie's previous work, dealing with themes of love, loss, and self-discovery. The album's sound was described as a mix of rock, pop, and country, with Lisa Marie's vocals being compared to those of her father.

--------

Lisa Marie Presley has been involved in various charity work and humanitarian efforts throughout her career. One of her most notable endeavors is her work with the Grammy Foundation, which aims to provide music education and resources to underprivileged children.

Lisa Marie Presley has received several awards and honors throughout her career. In 2004, she was awarded the Key to the City of Memphis, and in 2013, she was awarded the Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award for her contributions to music.

article:
2023 MTV Video Music Awards

The 2023 MTV Video Music Awards (VMAs) was an American award ceremony presented by MTV to recognize the best in the music video medium. The ceremony took place on September 12, 2023, at the Prudential Center in Newark, New Jersey, and was broadcast live on MTV.

Performances
------------

### Pre-show

The pre-show for the VMAs began at 8:00 PM EDT, featuring performances by several artists, including:

*  Tameca Jones
*  Ambar Lucid
*  Sofia Reyes

### Main show

The main show started at 9:00 PM EDT and featured a series of performances by notable artists, including:

*  Bad Bunny
*  Taylor Swift
*  Kendrick Lamar

#### Extended Play stage

The Extended Play stage was a new addition to the VMAs this year, featuring a series of performances by up-and-coming artists, including:

*  Babyface
*  MVC
*  Miracle

Rankings
----------

### Billboard

The VMAs ranked number one in the ratings on Billboard, with over 5 million viewers tuning in to watch the ceremony.

### USA Today

The VMAs were also a top trending topic on USA Today, with over 1 million people discussing the ceremony on social media.

Presenters
------------

### Pre-show

The pre-show for the VMAs featured several presenters, including:

*  Reggie Watts
*  Tatiana Maslany
*  Kelsea Ballerini

### Main show

The main show for the VMAs featured several presenters, including:

*  Chris Rock
*  Tiffany Haddish
*  Nicki Minaj

Winners and nominees
---------------------

### Voted categories

The following categories were voted on by the public:

*  Video of the Year
*  Artist of the Year
*  Song of the Year
*  Best Collaboration
*  Best New Artist

### Professional categories

The following categories were voted on by industry professionals:

*  Best Direction
*  Best Visual Effects
*  Best Editing
*  Best Choreography

Winners included Taylor Swift for Video of the Year, Kendrick Lamar for Artist of the Year, and Bad Bunny for Song of the Year.

Special awards
----------------

*  Michael Jackson Video Vanguard Award:  Beyoncé
*  Video Vanguard Award:  Taylor Swift

Voting system
----------------

### General voting period

The general voting period for the VMAs took place from July 24 to August 14, 2023.

### Double Days and Power Hours

During the voting period, there were several Double Days and Power Hours, where votes were doubled or tripled for a limited time.

### Instagram Story voting

The VMAs also featured an Instagram Story voting component, where fans could vote for their favorite artists and videos using Instagram Stories.

### Single-round voting

During the Instagram Story voting, fans could vote for their favorite artists and videos using a single-round voting system.

### Triple-round voting

For certain categories, fans could vote for their favorite artists and videos using a triple-round voting system.

### Four-round voting

For the Video of the Year category, fans could vote for their favorite artists and videos using a four-round voting system.

Ratings
--------

The VMAs drew in a record number of viewers this year, with over 5 million people tuning in to watch the ceremony.

Related events
----------------

### MTV VMA Fantasy

The MTV VMA Fantasy was a fantasy football-style game where fans could compete against each other to win prizes and bragging rights.

### VMA Block Party

The VMA Block Party was a live concert series that took place in several cities around the world, featuring performances by notable artists.

References
----------

Explanatory notes
------------------

*  The MTV Video Music Awards are an annual ceremony presented by MTV to recognize the best in the music video medium.
*  The VMAs have been held annually since 1984.
*  The ceremony is typically broadcast live on MTV and is one of the most-watched events on the network.

article:
**Donald Trump**

Donald John Trump is an American businessman, television personality, and politician who served as the 45th President of the United States from 2017 to 2021. He was born on June 14, 1946, in Queens, New York, to Mary Anne MacLeod and Frederick Christ Trump.

**Personal Life**

**Early Life**

Trump was the fourth of five children born to Frederick Christ Trump, a successful real estate developer, and Mary Anne MacLeod, a homemaker. He was raised in Jamaica, Queens, and attended the New York Military Academy in Cornwall, New York. Trump graduated from the academy in 1964 and enrolled in Fordham University, but transferred to the University of Pennsylvania, where he graduated with a Bachelor of Science degree in economics in 1968.

**Family**

Trump married Czech model Ivana Zelnickov in 1977, and they had three children, Donald Jr., Ivanka, and Eric. The couple divorced in 1992. In 1993, Trump married actress Marla Maples, but they divorced in 1999. In 2005, Trump married model Melania Knauss, and they have one son, Barron.

**Religion**

Trump was raised Presbyterian but has stated that he is a Christian. However, he has also been known to attend various churches and synagogues throughout his life.

**Health Habits**

Trump has been known to have a sedentary lifestyle and has been criticized for his eating habits. He has also been open about his struggles with weight and has attempted to lose weight through various diets.

**Wealth**

Trump's net worth is estimated to be over $3 billion, primarily due to his real estate business and licensing agreements. He has been involved in various business ventures, including casinos, hotels, and golf courses.

**Business Career**

**Real Estate**

Trump's real estate career began in the 1970s when he took over his father's company, Elizabeth Trump & Son. He expanded the company's operations and eventually renamed it The Trump Organization. Trump's most notable real estate projects include:

**Manhattan and Chicago Developments**

In the 1980s, Trump developed several high-end residential buildings in Manhattan and Chicago, including the Trump Tower and the Wollman Rink.

**Atlantic City Casinos**

In the 1980s, Trump opened two casinos in Atlantic City, New Jersey: the Trump Taj Mahal and the Trump Plaza.

**Clubs**

Trump has also been involved in various club ventures, including the Trump National Doral in Miami and the Trump International Golf Club in Westchester County, New York.

**Licensing of the Trump Brand**

Trump has licensed his name and image to various companies, including real estate developers, fashion designers, and food companies. He has also been involved in various branding and marketing campaigns.

**Side Ventures**

**Trump University**

In 2005, Trump launched a for-profit online university called Trump University, which offered real estate courses and training programs. However, the university was shut down in 2010 due to allegations of false advertising and consumer fraud.

**Foundation**

Trump has been involved in various charitable organizations, including the Donald J. Trump Foundation, which he established in 1987. However, the foundation has been criticized for its lack of transparency and its use of donations for personal expenses.

**Legal Affairs and Bankruptcies**

Trump has been involved in various legal disputes throughout his career, including several bankruptcies. In 1990, he filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection for his company, Trump Taj Mahal Associates. In 2004, he filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection for his company, Trump Entertainment Resorts.

**Media Career**

**Books**

Trump has written several books, including:

* "The Art of the Deal" (1987)
* "Surviving at the Top" (1990)
* "The America We Deserve" (2000)
* "The Way to the Top" (2004)
* "Great Again: How to Fix Our Crippled America" (2016)

**Film and Television**

Trump has appeared in various films and television shows, including:

* "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" (1990)
* "Home Alone 2: Lost in New York" (1992)
* "The Apprentice" (2004-2015)
* "The Celebrity Apprentice" (2008-2015)

**Political Career**

**Presidential Campaigns (2000-2016)**

**2016 Presidential Campaign**

In 2015, Trump announced his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination. He won the nomination in May 2016 and went on to defeat Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton in the general election.

**Campaign Rhetoric and Political Positions**

Trump's campaign rhetoric was characterized by his populist and nationalist message, which emphasized issues such as immigration, trade, and national security. He also proposed various policy initiatives, including:

* Building a wall along the US-Mexico border
* Implementing a temporary ban on Muslim immigration
* Withdrawing from the Trans-Pacific Partnership
* Implementing a 35% tariff on Chinese goods

**Financial Disclosures**

Trump's campaign was notable for its lack of financial disclosure. He refused to release his tax returns, citing an audit, and his campaign did not disclose its donor list until it was compelled to do so by a court order.

**Election to the Presidency**

On November 8, 2016, Trump won the presidential election, defeating Hillary Clinton in the Electoral College, 304-227. However, Clinton won the popular vote by nearly 3 million votes.

**Presidency (2017-2021)**

**Early Actions**

Trump's presidency was marked by several early actions, including:

* Signing an executive order to begin construction on the border wall
* Withdrawing from the Trans-Pacific Partnership
* Signing an executive order to freeze refugee admissions
* Issuing an executive order to ban travel from several predominantly Muslim countries

**Conflicts of Interest**

Trump's presidency was also marked by several conflicts of interest, including:

* His refusal to divest from his business interests
* His use of his presidency to promote his business ventures
* His failure to comply with transparency and ethics rules

**Domestic Policy**

**Economy**

Trump's economic policies were characterized by his emphasis on tax cuts and deregulation. He signed the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act in 2017, which lowered corporate and individual tax rates. He also rolled back several financial regulations, including the Dodd-Frank Act.

**Climate Change, Environment, and Energy**

Trump's climate change policies were characterized by his rejection of the Paris Agreement and his support for fossil fuels. He also rolled back several environmental regulations, including the Clean Power Plan.

**Deregulation**

Trump's deregulation policies were characterized by his emphasis on reducing bureaucratic red tape and increasing industry flexibility. He signed several executive orders aimed at reducing regulations, including the Executive Order on Reducing Regulation and Controlling Regulatory Costs.

**Health Care**

Trump's health care policies were characterized by his efforts to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act. He signed the American Health Care Act in 2017, which aimed to reduce Medicaid spending and repeal the individual mandate. However, the bill failed to pass the Senate.

**Social Issues**

Trump's social policies were characterized by his emphasis on issues such as immigration, crime, and national security. He signed several executive orders aimed at reducing immigration, including the Executive Order on Border Security and Immigration Enforcement Improvements.

**Pardons and Commutations**

Trump issued several pardons and commutations during his presidency, including:

* Pardoning former Maricopa County Sheriff Joe Arpaio
* Pardoning former Arizona Sheriff Richard Mack
* Commuting the sentence of former Illinois Governor Rod Blagojevich

**Immigration**

Trump's immigration policies were characterized by his emphasis on building a border wall and enforcing immigration laws. He signed several executive orders aimed at reducing immigration, including the Executive Order on Border Security and Immigration Enforcement Improvements.

**Travel Ban**

Trump's travel ban was aimed at restricting travel from several predominantly Muslim countries. He signed several executive orders aimed at implementing the ban, including the Executive Order on Protecting the Nation from Foreign Terrorist Entry into the United States.

**Family Separation at the Border**

Trump's family separation policy was aimed at separating families at the border. He signed an executive order aimed at implementing the policy, which led to widespread criticism and outrage.

**Trump Wall and Government Shutdown**

Trump's border wall and government shutdown were aimed at reducing immigration and enforcing border security. He signed a shutdown of the government in 2019, which lasted for 35 days.

**Foreign Policy**

**Trade**

Trump's trade policies were characterized by his emphasis on tariffs and trade protectionism. He signed several executive orders aimed at reducing trade deficits, including the Executive Order on Trade and Investment.

**Russia**

Trump's Russia policies were characterized by his emphasis on improving relations with Russia. He met with Russian President Vladimir Putin several times during his presidency, including at the G20 summit in 2017.

**China**

Trump's China policies were characterized by his emphasis on reducing trade deficits and enforcing trade laws. He imposed tariffs on Chinese goods, including steel and aluminum, and signed an executive order aimed at reducing Chinese investment in the US.

**North Korea**

Trump's North Korea policies were characterized by his emphasis on denuclearization and reducing tensions. He met with North Korean leader Kim Jong-un several times during his presidency, including at the Singapore summit in 2018.

**Afghanistan**

Trump's Afghanistan policies were characterized by his emphasis on reducing US military involvement. He announced a plan to withdraw US troops from Afghanistan in 2019, but later reversed the decision.

**Israel**

Trump's Israel policies were characterized by his emphasis on supporting Israel. He recognized Jerusalem as the capital of Israel in 2017 and moved the US embassy to Jerusalem.

**Saudi Arabia**

Trump's Saudi Arabia policies were characterized by his emphasis on supporting Saudi Arabia. He supported Saudi Arabia's intervention in Yemen and imposed sanctions on Saudi officials involved in the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

**Syria**

Trump's Syria policies were characterized by his emphasis on reducing US involvement. He withdrew US troops from Syria in 2019 and announced a plan to reduce US involvement in the country.

**Iran**

Trump's Iran policies were characterized by his emphasis on reducing US involvement. He withdrew the US from the Iran nuclear deal in 2018 and imposed sanctions on Iran.

**Personnel**

Trump's personnel policies were characterized by his emphasis on hiring loyalists and reducing the size of the federal government. He appointed several individuals to key positions, including:

* Secretary of State Mike Pompeo
* Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis
* Attorney General Jeff Sessions
* Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh

**Judiciary**

Trump's judiciary policies were characterized by his emphasis on appointing conservative judges. He appointed several judges to the federal bench, including:

* Supreme Court Justice Neil Gorsuch
* Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh
* Supreme Court Justice Amy Coney Barrett
* Federal Judge Thomas Hardiman

**COVID-19 Pandemic**

**Initial Response**

Trump's initial response to the COVID-19 pandemic was characterized by his emphasis on downplaying the severity of the outbreak. He compared the virus to the flu and stated that the US was prepared to handle the outbreak.

**White House Coronavirus Task Force**

Trump established a White House Coronavirus Task Force to coordinate the response to the pandemic. The task force was led by Vice President Mike Pence and included several health experts.

**World Health Organization**

Trump's response to the pandemic was also characterized by his criticism of the World Health Organization (WHO). He stated that the WHO was not doing enough to address the outbreak and that the US was considering withdrawing its funding from the organization.

**Pressure to Abandon Pandemic Mitigation Measures**

Trump faced pressure to abandon pandemic mitigation measures, including social distancing and mask mandates. He stated that the measures were too restrictive and that they were causing economic damage.

**Political Pressure on Health Agencies**

Trump also faced pressure to politicize the response to the pandemic. He stated that the health agencies were working too slowly to develop a vaccine and that he was considering replacing the head of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

**Outbreak at the White House**

An outbreak of COVID-19 occurred at the White House in September 2020. Several individuals, including the President and the First Lady, tested positive for the virus.

**Effects on the 2020 Presidential Campaign**

The COVID-19 pandemic had a significant impact on the 2020 presidential campaign. Trump's response to the pandemic was widely criticized, and his campaign struggled to regain momentum.

**Investigations**

**Russian Election Interference**

There were several investigations into Russian election interference during the Trump presidency. The investigations were led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller and focused on allegations that Russia had interfered in the 2016 presidential election.

**FBI Crossfire Hurricane and 2017 Counterintelligence Investigations**

The FBI launched an investigation into Russian election interference in 2016, code-named Crossfire Hurricane. The investigation was led by FBI Agent Peter Strzok and focused on allegations that Trump was compromised by Russia.

**Mueller Investigation**

The Mueller investigation was a follow-up to the Crossfire Hurricane investigation. The investigation was led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller and focused on allegations that Trump had obstructed justice and that Russia had interfered in the 2016 presidential election.

**First Impeachment**

Trump was impeached by the House of Representatives in December 2019 on charges of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress. The impeachment was related to his dealings with Ukraine and allegations that he had withheld military aid in exchange for investigations into his political opponents.

**Impeachment Trial in the Senate**

Trump's impeachment trial was held in the Senate in January 2020. The trial was led by Chief Justice John Roberts and focused on the charges of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress.

**2020 Presidential Campaign**

Trump's 2020 presidential campaign was marked by controversy and scandal. He faced criticism for his response to the COVID-19 pandemic and was accused of spreading misinformation about the virus.

**2020 Presidential Election**

Trump lost the 2020 presidential election to Joe Biden. He was defeated in the Electoral College, 306-232, and lost the popular vote by nearly 7 million votes.

**False Claims of Voting Fraud, Attempt to Prevent Presidential Transition**

Trump made several false claims of voting fraud and attempted to prevent the presidential transition. He refused to concede the election and made several baseless claims about the integrity of the vote.

**Concern about a Possible Coup Attempt or Military Action**

There was concern about a possible coup attempt or military action in the wake of the election. Trump's allies and supporters made several baseless claims about the legitimacy of the election, and there were fears that the situation could escalate.

**January 6 Capitol Attack**

The January 6 Capitol attack was a violent riot that occurred on January 6, 2021. The attack was inspired by Trump's claims of voting fraud and his calls for supporters to march on the Capitol.

**Second Impeachment**

Trump was impeached again by the House of Representatives in January 2021 on charges of inciting an insurrection. The impeachment was related to the January 6 Capitol attack and Trump's role in inciting the violence.

**Post-Presidency (2021-Present)**

**Business Activities**

Trump has continued to engage in business activities since leaving office. He has opened a new office in Mar-a-Lago and has been involved in several business ventures, including a new social media platform.

**Investigations, Criminal Indictments, and Civil Lawsuits**

Trump has been the subject of several investigations, criminal indictments, and civil lawsuits since leaving office. He has been accused of various crimes, including tax evasion and election interference.

**FBI Investigations**

The FBI has launched several investigations into Trump's activities since leaving office. The investigations have focused on allegations of tax evasion, election interference, and other crimes.

**Criminal Referral by the House January 6 Committee**

The House January 6 Committee has referred Trump to the Department of Justice for criminal prosecution. The referral is related to Trump's role in inciting the January 6 Capitol attack.

**Federal and State Criminal Indictments**

Trump has been indicted on several federal and state charges. The indictments are related to allegations of tax evasion, election interference, and other crimes.

**Criminal Conviction in the 2016 Campaign Fraud Case**

Trump was convicted of one count of campaign finance fraud in the 2016 campaign finance case. The conviction is related to allegations that Trump paid hush money to a former adult film star.

**Civil Judgments Against Trump**

Trump has been the subject of several civil judgments against him. The judgments are related to allegations of defamation, breach of contract, and other civil wrongdoing.

**2024 Presidential Campaign**

Trump has announced his candidacy for the 2024 presidential election. His campaign is expected to be marked by controversy and scandal, and he will face stiff competition from other Republican candidates.

**Public Image**

**Scholarly Assessment and Public Approval Surveys**

Trump's public image has been the subject of several scholarly assessments and public approval surveys. The assessments have focused on his leadership style, policies, and personal characteristics.

**False or Misleading Statements**

Trump has made several false or misleading statements about his policies, opponents, and other issues. The statements have been widely criticized and have damaged his public image.

**Promotion of Conspiracy Theories**

Trump has promoted several conspiracy theories, including the "Deep State" and the "Russian collusion" conspiracy. The theories have been widely debunked and have damaged his public image.

**Incitement of Violence**

Trump has been accused of inciting violence on several occasions, including the January 6 Capitol attack. The accusations have damaged his public image and have raised concerns about his fitness for office.

**Social Media**

Trump has been a prolific user of social media, including Twitter and Facebook. He has used the platforms to promote his policies, opponents, and other issues, and has been accused of spreading misinformation and inciting violence.

**Relationship with the Press**

Trump has had a contentious relationship with the press throughout his presidency and post-presidency. He has accused the press of being "fake news" and has made several baseless claims about the media.

**Racial Views**

Trump has been accused of having racist views and has made several statements that have been widely criticized. The accusations have damaged his public image and have raised concerns about his fitness for office.

**Misogyny and Allegations of Sexual Misconduct**

Trump has been accused of misogyny and has made several statements that have been widely criticized. He has also been accused of sexual misconduct and has been sued by several women who claim that he has harassed or assaulted them.

**Popular Culture**

Trump has been the subject of several references in popular culture, including music, film, and television. The references have often been critical of his policies and personal characteristics, and have damaged his public image.

article:
**Jawan (film)**

**Introduction**

Jawan is a 2023 Indian action thriller film directed by Atlee and produced by Gaurav Verma under the banner of AGS Cinemas. The film stars Shah Rukh Khan, Nayanthara, and Vijay Sethupathi in the lead roles. The film is a remake of the 2019 Malayalam film Lucifer.

**Plot**

The story follows the life of Vikram Rathore (Shah Rukh Khan), a former RAW agent who has retired from service. Vikram is married to a police officer, Saeeda (Nayanthara), and they have a daughter named Rukmini. However, their lives are turned upside down when Saeeda is killed in a terrorist attack. Vikram, who is still grieving, decides to join the police force to avenge his wife's death.

As Vikram delves deeper into the world of police work, he discovers that there is a mole within the force who is responsible for the terrorist attack. Vikram must use his skills to uncover the identity of the mole and bring them to justice. Along the way, he faces numerous challenges and obstacles, including a deadly terrorist named Dada Aslam (Vijay Sethupathi) who is determined to take him down.

**Cast**

* Shah Rukh Khan as Vikram Rathore
* Nayanthara as Saeeda Rathore
* Vijay Sethupathi as Dada Aslam
* Sanya Malhotra as Rukmini Rathore
* Sunil Grover as Sanjay Kumar
* Priyamani as Jaya Kumar
* Samuthirakani as IPS Officer

**Production**

### Development

The film was first announced in 2020, with Atlee confirming that he would be directing the film. The script was written by Atlee and K. V. Vijayendra Prasad. Production began in 2021, with Shah Rukh Khan and Nayanthara being cast in the lead roles.

### Casting

Shah Rukh Khan was the first actor to be cast in the film, with Atlee confirming that he would be playing the lead role. Nayanthara was cast as the female lead, with Vijay Sethupathi joining the cast as the antagonist.

### Filming

Filming began in 2021, with the shoot taking place in various locations across India, including Mumbai, Delhi, and Hyderabad. The film's action sequences were choreographed by Ravi Varma, with the cinematography being handled by Ravi K. Chandran.

### Post-production

The film's editing was handled by Ruben, with the VFX being handled by Red Chillies VFX. The music for the film was composed by Anirudh Ravichander, with the lyrics being written by Raqueeb Alam.

**Themes and influences**

The film explores several themes, including the impact of terrorism on families, the importance of loyalty, and the power of the human spirit. The film is influenced by several other films, including the Malayalam film Lucifer, which it is based on, as well as the Bollywood film Lakshya.

**Music**

The music for the film was composed by Anirudh Ravichander, with the lyrics being written by Raqueeb Alam. The film's soundtrack features several popular songs, including the title track "Jawan", which was released in 2023.

**Marketing**

The film's marketing campaign began in 2023, with the release of several promotional posters and teasers. The film's trailer was released in August 2023, with the film being promoted through various social media channels.

**Release**

### Theatrical

The film was released in theaters on September 7, 2023, in India and other countries. The film was released in multiple languages, including Hindi, Tamil, and Telugu.

### Distribution

The film was distributed by AGS Cinemas, with the film being released in over 4,000 screens across India.

### Home media

The film was released on digital platforms on October 14, 2023, with the film being available for streaming on various platforms, including Netflix and Amazon Prime Video.

**Reception**

### Box office

The film was a commercial success, grossing over ₹500 crore at the domestic box office and over ₹1,000 crore worldwide.

### Critical response

The film received positive reviews from critics, with many praising the film's action sequences, performances, and direction. The film holds a 7.5/10 rating on IMDB, with many viewers praising the film's engaging storyline and memorable performances.

**Accolades**

The film won several awards, including the Filmfare Award for Best Actor in a Leading Role (Shah Rukh Khan) and the IIFA Award for Best Performance in a Leading Role (Shah Rukh Khan).

**Future**

The film's success has led to a sequel being announced, with Atlee confirming that he will be directing the film.

**Notes**

The film's success has been attributed to its engaging storyline, memorable performances, and well-choreographed action sequences.

**References**

None

**External links**

None

# Liga 1 (Indonesia)

Liga 1, previously known as Super League, is the top-tier professional football league in Indonesia. It is managed by the Indonesian Football Association (PSSI) and is considered one of the most competitive and popular sports leagues in the country.

## History

### Origins

The history of Liga 1 dates back to 1921, when the Dutch East Indies Football Association (NEVO) was established, which marked the beginning of organized football in Indonesia. However, the first official top-tier league was established in 1922, with the winner being the Indonesian club, Voetbalbond Indo-Europeesche Vereeniging.

### Foundation

The modern version of Liga 1 was founded in 1994 as the first division of the Indonesian football league system. The league was initially known as the Liga Indonesia and was composed of 13 teams. The league was rebranded as the Super League in 2008 and later as Liga 1 in 2017.

### Dualism

Liga 1 has a long history of dualism, with two rival leagues, Liga 1 and the Indonesian Premier League (IPL), competing for dominance. The IPL was formed in 2010 as a rival to Liga 1, but it eventually merged with Liga 1 in 2017.

### Government intervention and FIFA suspension

Liga 1 has faced several challenges, including government intervention and a suspension by FIFA. In 2015, the PSSI was suspended by FIFA due to government interference, which led to the league being suspended. The suspension was lifted in 2016, and the league resumed in 2017.

### Name change

In 2017, the league was rebranded as Liga 1, a name that is derived from the Indonesian phrase "liga satu," which means "first league."

## Competition format

### Competition

Liga 1 is a professional football league that features 18 teams competing in a double round-robin format. The teams play each other twice, once at home and once away, with the team earning the most points declared the champion.

### Promotion and relegation

The bottom three teams in Liga 1 are relegated to the second division, Liga 2, while the top three teams in Liga 2 are promoted to Liga 1.

### Video assistant referee

Liga 1 introduced the use of video assistant referee (VAR) in 2019 to improve the accuracy of refereeing decisions.

article:
**Oppenheimer (film)**

Oppenheimer is a 2023 American biographical drama film directed by Christopher Nolan, who co-wrote the screenplay with the film's producer, Emma Thomas. The film is based on the life of J. Robert Oppenheimer, who played a crucial role in the development of the atomic bomb during World War II.

**Plot**

The film centers around Oppenheimer's life, from his early days as a young and ambitious scientist to his appointment as the director of the Manhattan Project, which was responsible for developing the atomic bomb. The film explores the moral and psychological complexities of Oppenheimer's journey, as he navigates the tensions between his scientific pursuits and the catastrophic consequences of his work.

The film also delves into Oppenheimer's personal life, including his relationships with his wife, Katherine "Kitty" Posen, and his lover, Jean Tatlock. The film portrays the strain that Oppenheimer's work and personal life put on his relationships, particularly with his wife, who struggles to cope with the secrecy and danger surrounding her husband's work.

Throughout the film, Oppenheimer grapples with the ethics of his work, as he comes to realize the devastating consequences of the atomic bomb. The film's climax depicts Oppenheimer's testimony before the Atomic Energy Commission, where he is questioned about his role in the development of the bomb and his involvement in the Trinity test.

**Cast**

The film features a talented ensemble cast, including:

* Cillian Murphy as J. Robert Oppenheimer
* Emily Blunt as Katherine "Kitty" Posen Oppenheimer
* Matt Damon as Leslie Groves
* Robert Downey Jr. as Lewis Strauss
* Benny Safdie as Edward Teller
* Rami Malek as David Greenglass
* Josh Hartnett as Ernest Lawrence
* Dane DeHaan as Kenneth Nichols
* Alden Ehrenreich as Richard Feynman
* Jack Quaid as Robert Bacher
* Florence Pugh as Jean Tatlock

**Production**

### Development

Oppenheimer has been in development for several years, with Christopher Nolan and Emma Thomas initially attached to the project in 2014. Nolan had long been fascinated by the life and work of J. Robert Oppenheimer, and he saw the film as an opportunity to explore the complexities of Oppenheimer's character and the historical context of the Manhattan Project.

### Writing

Nolan and Thomas co-wrote the screenplay for Oppenheimer, drawing on a wide range of sources, including Oppenheimer's own writings and the accounts of his colleagues and friends. The script underwent several drafts, with Nolan and Thomas working closely with the film's producers and other members of the cast and crew to develop the story and characters.

### Casting

The casting process for Oppenheimer was a long and complex one, with Nolan and Thomas working to assemble a talented ensemble cast that could bring the film's complex characters to life. Cillian Murphy was the first actor to be cast in the title role, followed by Emily Blunt, Matt Damon, and Robert Downey Jr.

### Filming

Principal photography on Oppenheimer began in April 2022 and continued for several months, with Nolan and his team shooting on location in various parts of the United States, including Los Alamos, New Mexico, and Washington, D.C. The film's cinematographer, Hoyte van Hoytema, used a range of innovative techniques to capture the film's complex and often disturbing imagery.

### Post-production

Post-production on Oppenheimer was a lengthy and complex process, with Nolan and his team working closely with the film's editors, visual effects artists, and sound designers to assemble the final cut of the film. The film's sound design and visual effects were particularly extensive, with Nolan and his team working to create a immersive and unsettling atmosphere that captures the complexity and danger of Oppenheimer's world.

**Music**

The music for Oppenheimer was composed by Ludwig Göransson, who worked closely with Nolan to develop a score that would complement the film's complex and often disturbing imagery. The score features a range of innovative and unsettling sounds, including discordant harmonies and percussive effects, that help to create a sense of tension and unease.

**Marketing**

The marketing campaign for Oppenheimer was extensive and complex, with Nolan and his team working to create a sense of anticipation and excitement for the film's release. The film's trailer was released in June 2023, and it quickly went viral, generating widespread buzz and interest in the film.

**Release**

### Theatrical

Oppenheimer was released theatrically on July 21, 2023, in the United States and Canada, and it quickly became one of the summer's biggest hits. The film was released in IMAX and 70mm formats, and it was accompanied by a range of innovative marketing and promotional materials, including a companion book and a series of interactive exhibits.

### Classifications and censorship

Oppenheimer was rated R for violence, disturbing images, and language by the Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA), and it was subject to censorship and classification in various countries around the world. In the United Kingdom, for example, the film was rated 18 for strong violence and disturbing scenes, while in Australia, it was rated M for mature themes and strong violence.

**Home media**

Oppenheimer was released on DVD and Blu-ray in September 2023, and it quickly became a bestseller. The film's home media release included a range of innovative and interactive features, including behind-the-scenes footage, deleted scenes, and a companion book.

**Reception**

### Box office

Oppenheimer was a major box office success, grossing over $400 million worldwide in its opening weekend. In the United States and Canada, the film grossed over $150 million, while in Japan, it grossed over $20 million.

### United States and Canada

In the United States and Canada, Oppenheimer was released in over 4,000 theaters, and it quickly became one of the summer's biggest hits. The film's opening weekend was the biggest of the summer, and it quickly became the number one film at the box office.

### Japan

In Japan, Oppenheimer was released in over 1,000 theaters, and it quickly became a major hit. The film's opening weekend was the biggest of the summer, and it quickly became the number one film at the box office.

### Other territories

In other territories around the world, Oppenheimer was also a major success, grossing over $100 million in Europe, over $50 million in Australia, and over $20 million in South Korea.

### Critical response

Oppenheimer received widespread critical acclaim, with many critics praising the film's complex and nuanced portrayal of J. Robert Oppenheimer's life and work. The film holds a 92% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, with many critics praising the film's performances, direction, and cinematography.

### Influence on legislation

Oppenheimer's portrayal of the atomic bomb and its devastating consequences has had a significant impact on the film's reception, with many critics and audiences praising the film's thought-provoking and unsettling portrayal of the bomb's effects. The film has also been credited with influencing legislation and policy related to nuclear energy and disarmament.

**Accuracy and omissions**

Oppenheimer is a dramatization of J. Robert Oppenheimer's life and work, and it is not a strictly accurate or comprehensive portrayal of his life. The film takes creative liberties with certain events and characters, and it omits others in order to focus on the central themes and storylines of the film.

**Accolades**

Oppenheimer has received widespread critical acclaim and numerous awards and nominations. The film has been nominated for several Academy Awards, including Best Picture, Best Director, and Best Actor for Cillian Murphy's performance.

* The film's title, Oppenheimer, is derived from the surname of the film's subject, J. Robert Oppenheimer.
* The film's score was composed by Ludwig Göransson, who worked closely with Christopher Nolan to develop a score that would complement the film's complex and often disturbing imagery.
* The film's cinematography was handled by Hoyte van Hoytema, who used a range of innovative techniques to capture the film's complex and often unsettling imagery.
